QAPair.Question: What is (are) Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: Geographic tongue is characterized by irregular patches on the surface of the tongue. This gives it a map-like appearance.

QAPair.Question: What causes Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: The exact cause of geographic tongue is unknown. It may be due to irritation from hot or spicy foods, or alcohol. The condition appears to be less common in smokers. The change in pattern on the surface of the tongue occurs when there is a loss of the tiny, finger-like projections, called papillae, on the tongue. These areas look flat as a result. The appearance of the tongue may change very quickly. The flat-looking areas may remain for more than a month.

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms include: Map-like appearance to the surface of the tongue, Patches that move from day to day, Smooth, red patches and sores (lesions) on the tongue, Soreness and burning pain (in some cases) ,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: Your health care provider will diagnose this condition by looking at your tongue. Most of the time, tests are not needed.

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: No treatment is needed. Antihistamine gel or steroid- or tacrolimus-containing mouth rinses may help ease discomfort.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: Geographic tongue is a harmless condition. It may be uncomfortable and last for a long time.

Question.qtype: when to contact a medical professional

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your provider if the symptoms last longer than 10 days. Seek medical help right away if: You have breathing problems., Your tongue is severely swollen., You have problems speaking, chewing, or swallowing. ,

QAPair.Question: How to prevent Geographic tongue ?
QAPair.Answer: Avoid irritating your tongue with hot or spicy food or alcohol if you are prone to this condition.
